problem.markdown:
>>In the transition equations of the exponential distribution (slide 47), why is the rate of change in probability for state 1,\(\frac{d\pi(1,t)}{dt}\) independent of the value of \(\pi(0,t)\)?<<
( ) Because \(\pi(0,t)\) is contained in \(\mu\). (x) Because the state cannot change from state 0 to state 1. ( ) Because rates of probability change of one state is never influenced by the probability of being in another state.
[explanation] Because the state cannot change from state 0 to state 1, recall in slide 46, \(\pi(1,t + \delta t)= (1 - \mu \delta t)\pi(1,t)+(0)\pi(0,t)+o(\delta t)\), and therefore, \(\frac{d\pi(1,t)}{dt}\) does not depend on \(\pi(0,t)\). [explanation]
